title-group.article-title: Modeling and simulation of a wind farm in the presence of power electronic devices for the enhancement of transient stability

abstract.p: A comprehensive comparative study is made of a pitch control system and shunt flexible AC transmission system (FACTS) devices in order to improve large wind farm operation. Transient stability analysis of a large wind farm in the presence of superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES), static synchronous compensator (STATCOM), static var compensator (SVC) and pitch controller is performed. The proposed control strategy of the STATCOM is based on PWM control; both the angle and the magnitude of the converter output voltage and the proposed SMES control system is based on a PWM voltage-source converter and a two-quadrant DC–DC chopper using an insulated-gate bipolar transistor (IGBT). Furthermore, robust control systems are designed for SVC and pitch controllers. To investigate the operation of the wind farm with contribution of these devices, two scenarios are considered and simulated. First, extensive analysis of a symmetrical three-phase fault and its effects on system operation is carried out. A permanent fault due to unsuccessful reclosing is analysed; this is one of the most noticeable features of this study. PSCAD/EMTDC software is used for modeling and simulation of the system components and proposed control strategies for power electronic interfaces. System performance analysis under different operating conditions and performance indices show the effectiveness of the proposed controllers even when a severe fault is applied.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Wind energy’s presence in electric power systems has dramatically grown over the past decade and will continue to grow worldwide as many countries have planned future developments.1 One of the simplest methods of operating a fixed-speed wind turbine generation system is to use a squirrel-cage induction generator connected directly to the power grid, because an induction generator is the most cost-effective and robust machine for wind energy conversion. However, induction generators have stability problems similar to the transient stability of synchronous machines. Therefore, it is important to analyse the transient stability of power systems, including wind power stations.2 There are various methods to analyse and improve wind farm transient stability. One of these methods is a pitch controller, which is generally fitted to wind turbines. Although the main purpose of the pitch controller is to maintain output power of the wind generator at the rated level when wind speed is above the rated speed, it can also enhance the transient stability of the wind generator by controlling the rotor speed.3

With the recent development of power electronic converter/inverter technology, static synchronous compensator (STATCOM) and static var compensator (SVC), which are flexible AC transmission system (FACTS) devices, have been utilized as tools for enhancing the operation of wind farms.4 STATCOM has the ability of reactive power control and to compensate for reactive power relative to the power system. Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) devices are large superconducting coils capable of storing electric energy in the magnetic field generated by DC current flowing through them. The real power as well as the reactive power can be absorbed by (charging) or released from (discharging) the SMES coil according to system power requirements.3

The effect of FACTS devices on wind farm operation has been demonstrated in several trials, for instance see Cartwright et al.,5 where stability enhancement of wind farms using STATCOM is discussed. In this reference, not only was the power system model simple, but the STATCOM control strategy was also relatively simple. The effect of STATCOM and SMES systems for analysing wind farm power and voltage regulation is reported in Ali and Wu,3 while an aggregate wind farm model is used, which is not suitable for experimental cases. In Ali et al.6 a fuzzy controller using an insulated-gate bipolar transistor (IGBT) for SMES is proposed, but it is not suitable for large power-system applications. In Muyeen et al.7 power-system stability enhancement is proposed by using a fuzzy logic-controlled energy capacitor system (ECS), where only faults with successful reclosing are analysed. In Kinjo et al.8 a three-phase fault is analysed, where a one mass-lumped model of a wind turbine is used. But for evaluation of fault effects on wind turbines systems, a two-mass drive-train model at the least should be considered.9

In this paper a comprehensive comparative study of pitch control systems and shunt FACTS devices is made in order to improve large wind farm operation. Transient stability analysis of operation of a large wind farm in the presence of a SMES, STATCOM, SVC and a pitch controller is performed. PSCAD/EMTDC software (https://hvdc.ca/pscad/) is used for modeling and simulation of the system components and proposed control strategies for power electronic interfaces. The proposed STATCOM control strategy is based on PWM controlling both the angle and the magnitude of the converter output voltage. The proposed SMES control system is based on a PWM voltage-source converter (VSC) and a two-quadrant DC-DC chopper using an IGBT. Furthermore, robust control systems are designed for SVC and wind turbine blade angle. In order to investigate operation of the proposed controllers, the system is simulated for two scenarios with different disturbances.

The paper is organized as follows: section 2 describes the case study; section 3 presents wind farm components; the pitch controller is presented in section 4; the SVC controller is discussed in section 5; SMES and STATCOM control schemes are described in sections 6 and 7, respectively; the simulations are presented and discussed in section 8 and, finally in section 9, a conclusion is provided.

sec.title: 2. Case study
sec.p: Figure 1 shows the considered power system. The wind farm includes 10 wind turbine induction generators, and the rated power for the wind farm is 50 MW. The considered wind farm is constructed based on 5 MW wind turbine induction generators, which are based on a two-mass drive train model. The wind generators are connected to the grid through transformers and a common transmission line. The space between turbines is 350 m. Considered wind turbine and transformer parameters are listed in Appendix 1.

sec.p: In this study a squirrel-cage induction machine is coupled to each wind turbine. sec.title: 4. Pitch controller
sec.p: The main aim of utilizing a blade angle controller for a wind turbine is to maintain the machine output power within the rated value when wind speed is over the rated speed. Moreover, it can improve transient stability by controlling the rotor speed. In this study, the pitch control system model of the wind turbine is based on the PSCAD/EMTDC blade angle controller that is shown in Figure 4. As shown in Figure 4, ωm is mechanical speed, ωref is reference speed, Pref and Pg are power demand and power output of the machine, respectively. Here Ks, Kp and Ki are the gain, proportional gain and integral gain, respectively, and Gm is the gain multiplier and K4 is blade actuator integral gain.15 When the wind speed rises, to maintain the machine output power at the rated value, the blade angle controller increases the angle of the blade. Corresponding to Figure 2, an increase of β causes lowering of the power coefficient; consequently the obtained power of the turbine is reduced.

sec.title: 5. Modeling the SVC
sec.p: The SVC is a device that provides near-instantaneous reactive power support. It can be used for voltage control, improving system stability, balancing three-phase unbalanced loads and increasing transmission capacity. The most common type of SVC consists of a thyristor-switched capacitor (TSC)/thyristor-controlled reactor (TCR) combination; this configuration was chosen for addition to the wind turbine model.16 The schematic diagram of the SVC is based on the work by Gole and Sood.17 The proposed SVC configuration is a 12-pulse TSC/TCR SVC system. The model includes its own transformer, which consists of a star-connected primary winding and dual secondary windings (one star-connected and one delta-connected). The block diagram of the SVC controller is shown in Figure 5. It consists of a three-phase bus voltage measurement block and a three-phase current measurement block. These measurements are used to indicate the reactive power Qsvc of the compensator. The magnitude of the voltage measurement VL is used to derive a droop. This is followed by a block that adds the droop, proportional to the reactive current of the SVC, to the magnitude of the measured voltage. This signal is then filtered. The error between this filtered signal and the reference bus voltage (Vref) is passed through a PI controller that results in a reactive power order (BSVS) to the SVC. This order is split by the allocator into a capacitor on/off signal for the TSC and a reactive power demand (BTCR) from the TCR. Hysteresis between capacitor stages is built into the model. A relationship representing the non-linear dependence between BTCR and the required firing angle α is consulted and the required α-order passed on to the PLL-based firing system in the SVC model.

sec.title: 6.1. SMES unit
sec.p: The SMES is a DC current device that stores energy in a magnetic field. The DC current flowing through a superconducting wire in a large magnet creates the magnetic field. During SMES operation, the magnet coils have to remain in the superconducting state. A refrigerator in the cryogenic system maintains the required temperature for proper superconducting operation.18 In Figure 1 the SMES unit is shown inside the dotted line. The SMES system includes a transformer (66/0.77 kV) with 0.2 pu leakage reactance, a 6-pulse PWM VSC using an IGBT, a DC link capacitor, a two-quadrant DC–DC chopper using an IGBT and a superconducting coil. sec.title: 6.2. PWM VSC
sec.p: The PWM VSC as shown in Figure 1 provides a power electronic interface between the AC power system and the superconducting coil. The purpose of this controller is to keep the magnitude of the terminal voltage of the wind farm at the rated value. In this way, corresponding to Figure 6, the DC reference voltage is compared to the DC bus voltage and finally constructs the angle of the grid-side VSC. The difference between the AC voltage reference and the AC terminal voltage of the wind farm determines the modulation index for the grid-side converter. Then, the reference signals for PWM are constructed while the PLL synchronizes the control signals with grid voltage. PI controller parameters are determined by a trial-and-error method.3,6

sec.title: 6.3. Two-quadrant DC–DC chopper
sec.p: The superconducting coil is charged or discharged by adjusting the average (i.e. DC) voltage across the coil to positive or negative values by means of the DC–DC chopper duty cycle D. When the duty cycle is greater than 0.5 the coil is charging; and when the duty cycle is less than 0.5 the coil is discharging. When the unit is in standby mode, the coil current is maintained at a constant, independent of the storage level, by adjusting the chopper duty cycle to 50%, resulting in the net voltage across the superconducting winding becoming zero.18 The control scheme of the DC–DC chopper is shown inside the dotted line in Figure 6. In order to generate the gate signals for the chopper IGBT, the PWM reference signal is compared with the sawtooth carrier signal, as shown in Figure 6.

sec.title: 7. Modeling the STATCOM
sec.p: The two-level VSC-based STATCOM is shown inside the dashed line in Figure 1. The STATCOM is one of the most significant devices in FACTS technology, where it is used to compensate for the reactive power. The installation of the STATCOM into the power system is by shunt connection at the point of common coupling.19 The reactive power of the STATCOM is produced by means of power electronic equipment of the VSC type. The VSC converts the DC voltage into a three-phase set of output voltages with the desired amplitude, frequency and phase. However, it can only absorb/inject reactive power, and consequently is limited in its degree of freedom and sustained action.20 The STATCOM control scheme is depicted in Figure 6. The purpose of the control is to maintain a constant voltage magnitude at the wind farm terminal (Figure 1 point K) by providing or absorbing necessary reactive power from or to the VSC-based STATCOM. For this purpose, as shown in Figure 6, the DC reference voltage is compared to the DC bus voltage and finally constructs the angle. Comparison between the AC voltage reference and the AC bus voltage determines the modulation index. After that, the reference signals for PWM are constructed. As shown in Figure 7, the PLL17 synchronizes the control signals with grid voltage. The controller gains are determined using a trial-and-error method.

sec.title: 8. Simulation results and discussion
sec.p: In this study the SMES, STATCOM, SVC and pitch controller are used to improve the transient stability of a large wind farm. In addition, the wind farm and the above-mentioned devices are modeled and simulated through PSCAD/EMTDC software as described in previous sections. The effectiveness and robustness of the proposed controllers for the operation of the wind farm are evaluated by simulation studies in PSCAD/EMTDC but the figures are plotted in MATLAB R2009a. The studies are focused on various operating conditions and compared with various configurations. For further investigation, two scenarios are presented below.

sec.title: 8.1. Scenario 1
sec.p: In this scenario, a symmetrical three-phase fault occurs at the point F1 as shown in the system model in Figure 1. The fault occurs at time t = 5 s, circuit breakers (CBs) are opened at t = 5.1 s and are reclosed at t = 6 s. In this case, it is assumed that wind speed is constant and equivalent to the rated speed of 11.8 m/s, because wind speed does not change dramatically during the short time interval of the simulation. Terminal voltage of the wind farm is shown in Figure 8. According to this figure, each of the proposed devices can maintain the terminal voltage at the rated level. Moreover, it is clear that the performance of the SMES is better than that of the other devices. As can be seen in Figure 9, active power can be restored to its steady-state value due to the operation of the proposed controllers. Figure 10 shows the rotor speed of one of the wind farm induction generators. It is evident that, due to utilization of the proposed devices, the induction generator becomes stable. Reactive power of the SMES, STATCOM and SVC are shown in Figure 11. According to these figures, it is obvious that although each of the proposed devices (SMES, STATCOM, SVC and pitch controller) can make the wind farm stable, simulation results show that the performance of the SMES is the best. Compared to the SVC, the STATCOM provides better performance. The response of the pitch controller is much slower than that of the other proposed devices.

sec.title: 8.2. Scenario 2
sec.p: In this scenario, similar to the previous section, a three-phase fault occurs at the same point F1 in Figure 1. The fault occurs at t = 5 s, CBs on the fault lines are opened at t = 5.1 s and reclosed again at t = 6 s. In this section it is considered that the reclosing of the CBs is unsuccessful because of a permanent fault. Hence, the CBs are reopened at t = 6.1 s. Responses of terminal voltage and active power of the wind farm are shown in Figures 12 and 13, respectively. Furthermore, rotor speed of one of the wind farm induction generators is depicted in Figure 14. Based on these figures, it is clearly seen that the wind farm dynamic responses can be restored and stabilized with the contribution of the proposed compensation devices. Reactive power of the SMES, STATCOM and SVC are shown in Figure 15. As shown in these figures, it is reasonably clear that the SMES unit can get better responses. The SMES, STATCOM, and SVC can make the wind farm stable, but the pitch control method cannot stabilize the overall system well. Consequently, the response of the wind farm in the presence of a SMES regarding transient stability is quick. Moreover, performance of the STATCOM is better than the SVC.

sec.p: To demonstrate the effect of the proposed compensation devices, three performance indices are defined, as follows:3

ΔV, ΔP and Δω denote the terminal voltage deviations, the real power deviations and the rotor speed of the wind farm induction generator, respectively, and T is the simulation time. The lower values of these indices show better performance of the system. Numerical results of the performance and robustness of the proposed controllers for all of the scenarios are shown in Figure 16 and Table 1. In Figure 16 the results obtained using the proposed devices are compared. For example, according to Figure 16, in the first scenario the value of Vlt when a SMES is utilized is 0.615 while for the STATCOM or SVC it is 0.945 and 1.57, respectively. Furthermore, the value of Vlt when the pitch controller is applied is 6.06. For the second scenario in which a permanent fault occurs, the value of Vlt for the wind farm system with a contribution from the SMES is reduced by 38.12% in comparison with using the STATCOM. Moreover, in this scenario, the value of Vlt when the STATCOM is utilized is decreased by 66.13% compared with the SVC. According to Table 1, in the first scenario, under the fault condition, the value of Pow for the wind farm system in the presence of the SMES is reduced by 34.03% in comparison with the wind farm with the contribution of the STATCOM. Also in this scenario, the value of Pow when the STATCOM is applied is decreased by 2.31% in comparison with the SVC. On the other hand, in the second scenario, compared to the pitch controller for the wind farm system, the value of Pow for the wind farm system in the presence of the SVC declined by 97.12%. Also, for further investigation of transient stability of the wind farm, Spd as a performance index is defined. According to Table 1, in the second scenario the value of Spd for the SMES is decreased by 28.45% in comparison with the value of Spd for the STATCOM. In addition, the value of Spd for the STATCOM is declined by 68.46% and 98.43% in comparison with the value of Spd for the SVC and pitch controller, respectively. Based on the above discussions and comparisons, it can be said that the performance of the SMES is the best. Compared to the SVC, the STATCOM provides better performance. The response of the pitch controller is much slower than that of the other proposed devices.

sec.title: 8. Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper a comprehensive comparative investigation on the transient stability enhancement problem of a large wind farm in the presence of a SMES, STATCOM, SVC and pitch control system has been performed. PSCAD/EMTDC software has been used for modeling and simulation of the system components and proposed control strategies for power electronic interfaces. In order to show the excellent operation of the proposed controllers, the system has been simulated for two scenarios with different disturbances. Firstly, extensive analysis of a symmetrical three-phase fault has been carried out. Next, a permanent fault because of unsuccessful reclosing has been analysed; this is one of the most notable features of this study. Results showed that the system with a contribution from the SMES has the best operation. Compared to the SVC, the STATCOM provides better performance. The response of the pitch controller is much slower than that of the other proposed devices. The system performance characteristics in terms of Vlt, Pow and Spd indices expose exceptional performances from the proposed controllers.

bio.p: Peyman Farhang was born in Gorgan, Iran, in 1986. He received his BS in Electrical Engineering from Mazandaran University, Iran, in 2009, and his MS in Electrical Engineering from University of Zanjan, Iran, in 2012. He is a member of the Young Researchers Club (YRC), Behshahr branch, Iran. His research interests are the control and stabilization of power systems, the application of intelligent methods in power systems, renewable energy and FACTS devices to power system control design.

Saeid Jalilzadeh was born in Iran. He received his BS and MS from Tabriz University, Tabriz, Iran, in 1987 and 1991, respectively. his PhD degree in Electrical Engineering from Iran University of Science and Technology (IUST), Tehran, Iran in 2005. Currently, he is an Associated Professor in the Department of Power Engineering, University of Zanjan, Iran. His research interests are power system contingency analysis, power quality, renewable energy, power system dynamics and stability and FACTS devices.

His research interests are: reactive power control, power system dynamics, power quality, renewable energy and FACTS devices.
